message_text:
<paper>
Paper Title: Formal Synthesis of Stochastic Systems via Control Barrier Certificates
Paper Abstract: This paper focuses on synthesizing control policies for discrete-time\nstochastic control systems together with a lower bound on the probability that\nthe systems satisfy the complex temporal properties. The desired properties of\nthe system are expressed as linear temporal logic (LTL) specifications over\nfinite traces. In particular, our approach decomposes the given specification\ninto simpler reachability tasks based on its automata representation. We then\npropose the use of so-called \\emph{control barrier certificate} to solve those\nsimpler reachability tasks along with computing the corresponding controllers\nand probability bounds. Finally, we combine those controllers to obtain a\nhybrid control policy solving the considered problem. Under some assumptions,\nwe also provide two systematic approaches for uncountable and finite input sets\nto search for control barrier certificates. We demonstrate the effectiveness of\nthe proposed approach on a room temperature control and lane-keeping of a\nvehicle modeled as a four-dimensional single-track kinematic model. We compare\nour results with the discretization-based methods in the literature.\n
</paper>

<paper_classification>
"contribution" = proposes something new (method, technique, dataset, framework, benchmark, etc.)
"survey" = literature review, overview, meta-analysis, position papers (only references existing work)
</paper_classification>

<entity_types>
task      - Problem being solved (image classification, theorem proving, protein folding)
method    - Technique, algorithm, procedure (gradient descent, CRISPR, induction)
data      - Datasets, databases, benchmarks (ImageNet, MNIST, arXiv corpus)
artifact  - Pre-built: trained models, proof libraries (GPT-4, Mathlib, Cas9)
tool      - Software, instruments, platforms (PyTorch, Lean prover, microscope)
concept   - Abstract ideas, theories, frameworks (attention, category theory)
other     - Entities that don't fit above categories
</entity_types>

<relations>
uses     - Anything EXISTING that the paper uses (methods, datasets, tools, concepts, tasks)
proposes - Anything NEW/NOVEL that the paper creates or introduces

VALIDATION REQUIREMENTS:
- ALL papers MUST have at least 1 "uses" (papers always build on existing work)
- CONTRIBUTION papers MUST have at least 1 "proposes" (they must create something new)
</relations>

<output_json>
{
  "paper_type": "contribution" or "survey",
  "triples": [
    {
      "name": "Wikipedia Article Title",
      "relation": "uses|proposes",
      "entity_type": "task|method|data|artifact|tool|concept|other",
      "wikipedia_url": "https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/...",
      "relevance": "Why this matters (1 sentence)"
    }
  ]
}
</output_json>

<YOUR_TODO_LIST>
FIRST, add ALL of these to your todo list with "TodoWrite" tool:

CRITICAL: Todo content must be copied exactly as is written here, with NO CHANGES. These todos are intentionally detailed so that another LLM could read each one without any external context and understand exactly what it has to do.

1. Read ./triples_output.json. Classify paper as "contribution" or "survey". Edit triples_output.json to set paper_type field.

2. List ALL triples EXPLICITLY mentioned in title/abstract. For each, determine entity_type and relation.

3. For each triple: Use WebSearch tool with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] to search "[entity name]" to find the correct Wikipedia article. IMPORTANT: Always include allowed_domains parameter to restrict to English Wikipedia.

4. Edit triples_output.json to add all triples. For each triple:
   - name: Use the Wikipedia article title (e.g., "Gradient descent" not "gradient descent algorithm")
   - relation: how paper relates to entity (uses or proposes)
   - entity_type: one of task, method, data, artifact, tool, concept, other
   - wikipedia_url: The Wikipedia URL from search results (must start with https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/)
   - relevance: 1 sentence explaining why it matters

5. Run validation: python validate_triple_json.py

6. If validation errors: Fix the errors (use WebSearch with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] again if needed for incorrect URLs), edit triples_output.json, and rerun validation. MUST REPEAT until validation passes.

<CRITICAL_WEBSEARCH_INSTRUCTIONS>
When using WebSearch, you MUST use the allowed_domains parameter:
WebSearch(query="[your query]", allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"])

This ensures only English Wikipedia results are returned. Do NOT search without allowed_domains.
</CRITICAL_WEBSEARCH_INSTRUCTIONS>
</YOUR_TODO_LIST>

Begin now.

## Summary of Automata Theory

I've found comprehensive information about automata theory. Here are the key findings:

### Definition and Scope

Automata theory is the study of abstract machines and automata, as well as the computational problems that can be solved using them.(no content)It is a theory in theoretical computer science with close connections to cognitive science and mathematical logic.

### Key Concepts

An automaton is an abstract self-propelled computing device which follows a predetermined sequence of operations automatically.(no content)An automaton with a finite number of states is called a finite automaton (FA) or finite-state machine (FSM).(no content)Automata theory is closely related to formal language theory, where automata are used as finite representations of formal languages that may be infinite.

### Applications

Automata play a major role in the theory of computation, compiler construction, artificial intelligence, parsing and formal verification.

### Historical Development

The theory of abstract automata was developed in the mid-20th century in connection with finite automata.(no content)In 1956, the publication of Automata Studies collected work by scientists including Claude Shannon and John von Neumann, after which "automata theory emerged as a relatively autonomous discipline".

## Stochastic Control

Based on the search results, here's an overview of stochastic control:

### Definition
Stochastic control (also called stochastic optimal control) is a sub field of control theory that deals with the existence of uncertainty either in observations or in the noise that drives the evolution of the system.

### Key Characteristics
A stochastic control problem is one in which the evolution of the state variables is subjected to random shocks from outside the system.(no content)In typical stochastic control problems, it is assumed that there exist random noise and disturbances in the model and the controller, and the control design must take into account these random deviations.

### Mathematical Approach
The objective is to maximize either an integral of a concave function of a state variable over a horizon from time zero to a terminal time T, or a concave function of a state variable at some future date T.(no content)In cases where the maximization is an integral of a concave function of utility over an horizon, dynamic programming is used.

### Applications
The field of stochastic control has developed greatly since the 1970s, particularly in its applications to finance, with Robert Merton using stochastic control to study optimal portfolios of safe and risky assets.(no content)This technique is widely used in Financial Mathematics to determine optimal investment strategies in the market.

### Fundamental Principles
The separation principle is one of the fundamental principles of stochastic control theory, which states that the problems of optimal control and state estimation can be decoupled under certain conditions.

Based on the search results, here's what I found about Linear Temporal Logic:

## Overview

Linear temporal logic or linear-time temporal logic (LTL) is a modal temporal logic with modalities referring to time.(no content)In LTL, one can encode formulae about the future of paths, e.g., a condition will eventually be true, a condition will be true until another fact becomes true, etc.

## Applications

LTL formulas are commonly used to express constraints, specifications, or processes that a system should follow.(no content)Temporal logic has found an important application in formal verification, where it is used to state requirements of hardware or software systems.

## Model Checking

The field of model checking aims to formally verify whether a system meets a given specification. In the case of automata-theoretic model checking, both the system of interest and a specification are expressed as separate finite-state machines, or automata, and then compared to evaluate whether the system is guaranteed to have the specified property.

## Types of Properties

There are two main types of properties that can be expressed using linear temporal logic: safety properties usually state that something bad never happens, while liveness properties state that something good keeps happening.

## Extensions

Timed propositional temporal logic (TPTL) is an extension of propositional linear temporal logic (LTL) in which variables are introduced to measure times between two events.(no content)Metric temporal logic (MTL) is a special case of temporal logic. It is an extension of temporal logic in which temporal operators are replaced by time-constrained versions like until, next, since and previous operators.

Links: [{"title":"Linear temporal logic - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Linear_temporal_logic"},{"title":"Talk:Linear temporal logic - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Talk:Linear_temporal_logic"},{"title":"Linear temporal logic to Büchi automaton - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Linear_temporal_logic_to_B%C3%BCchi_automaton"},{"title":"Metric temporal logic - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Metric_temporal_logic"},{"title":"Temporal logic - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Temporal_logic"},{"title":"EXPSPACE - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/EXPSPACE"},{"title":"Timed propositional temporal logic - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Timed_propositional_temporal_logic"},{"title":"Signal (model checking) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Signal_(model_checking)"},{"title":"Kristin Yvonne Rozier - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kristin_Yvonne_Rozier"},{"title":"Category:Temporal logic - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Category:Temporal_logic"}]

Based on the search results, here's what I found about Linear Temporal Logic:

## Overview

Linear temporal logic or linear-time temporal logic (LTL) is a modal temporal logic with modalities referring to time.(no content)In LTL, one can encode formulae about the future of paths, e.g., a condition will eventually be true, a condition will be true until another fact becomes true, etc.

## Applications

LTL formulas are commonly used to express constraints, specifications, or processes that a system should follow.(no content)Temporal logic has found an important application in formal verification, where it is used to state requirements of hardware or software systems.

## Model Checking

The field of model checking aims to formally verify whether a system meets a given specification. In the case of automata-theoretic model checking, both the system of interest and a specification are expressed as separate finite-state machines, or automata, and then compared to evaluate whether the system is guaranteed to have the specified property.

## Types of Properties

There are two main types of properties that can be expressed using linear temporal logic: safety properties usually state that something bad never happens, while liveness properties state that something good keeps happening.

## Extensions

Timed propositional temporal logic (TPTL) is an extension of propositional linear temporal logic (LTL) in which variables are introduced to measure times between two events.(no content)Metric temporal logic (MTL) is a special case of temporal logic. It is an extension of temporal logic in which temporal operators are replaced by time-constrained versions like until, next, since and previous operators.

Web search results for query: "Reachability problem"

Links: [{"title":"Reachability problem - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Reachability_problem"},{"title":"Reachability - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Reachability"},{"title":"Reachability analysis - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Reachability_analysis"},{"title":"SL (complexity) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/SL_(complexity)"},{"title":"NL-complete - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/NL-complete"},{"title":"International Conference on Reachability Problems - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/International_Conference_on_Reachability_Problems"},{"title":"Configuration graph - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Configuration_graph"},{"title":"Context-free language reachability - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Context-free_language_reachability"},{"title":"Weak reference - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Weak_reference"},{"title":"Directed acyclic graph - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Directed_Acyclic_Graph"}]

## Results for "Reachability problem"

Based on the search results, here's what I found about the reachability problem:

### Definition
A reachability problem consists of checking whether a given set of target states can be reached starting from a fixed set of initial states.

### Graph Theory Context
In graph theory, reachability refers to the ability to get from one vertex to another within a graph.(no content)The reachability problem in an oriented graph described explicitly is NL-complete.(no content)Reingold, in a 2008 article, proved that the reachability problem for a non-oriented graph is in LOGSPACE.

### Applications

**In Model Checking and Planning:** In model checking, reachability corresponds to a property of liveliness. In planning, more precisely in classical planning, one is interested in knowing if one can attain a state from an initial state from a description of actions.

**In Petri Nets:** The reachability problem in a Petri net is decidable. Since 1976, it is known that this problem is EXPSPACE-hard.(no content)In 2022 it was shown to be complete for Ackermann function time complexity.

**In Distributed Systems:** Reachability analysis is a solution to the reachability problem in the particular context of distributed systems. It is used to determine which global states can be reached by a distributed system which consists of a certain number of local entities that communicated by the exchange of messages.

### Academic Research
The International Conference on Reachability Problems series is an annual academic conference which gathers together researchers from diverse disciplines and backgrounds interested in reachability problems that appear in algebraic structures, computational models, hybrid systems, infinite games, logic and verification.

Web search results for query: "Vehicle dynamics kinematic model"

Links: [{"title":"Vehicle dynamics - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Vehicle_dynamics"},{"title":"Kinematics - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kinematics"},{"title":"Vehicle Dynamics Integrated Management - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Vehicle_Dynamics_Integrated_Management"},{"title":"Category:Vehicle dynamics - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Category:Vehicle_dynamics"},{"title":"Rigid body dynamics - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rigid_body_dynamics"},{"title":"Dynamical simulation - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Multibody_simulation"},{"title":"Bicycle and motorcycle dynamics - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Motorcycle_dynamics"},{"title":"Dymola - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dymola"},{"title":"Traffic flow - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Traffic_flow"},{"title":"Automotive suspension design process - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Automotive_suspension_design"}]

Based on the web search results, here's an overview of vehicle dynamics kinematic models:

## Vehicle Dynamics and Kinematic Models

Vehicle dynamics is the study of vehicle motion, e.g., how a vehicle's forward movement changes in response to driver inputs, propulsion system outputs, ambient conditions, air/surface/water conditions, etc.(no content)Vehicle dynamics is a part of engineering primarily based on classical mechanics and may be applied for motorized vehicles (such as automobiles), bicycles and motorcycles, aircraft, and watercraft.

### Model Approaches

The dynamic behavior of vehicles can be analyzed as straightforwardly as a simple spring mass system, through a three-degree of freedom (DoF) bicycle model, to a large degree of complexity using a multibody system simulation package such as MSC ADAMS or Modelica.

### Kinematic Analysis

In the context of suspension design, kinematics describe how important characteristics change as the suspension moves, typically in roll or steer. For example, the actual kinematic steering angle is a function of the steering angle and the steering axis angle.

### Simulation Tools

Commercial packages such as CarSim have become widely used in industry for rapidly evaluating hundreds of test conditions much faster than real time, and vehicle models are often simulated with advanced controller designs provided as software in the loop (SIL) with controller design software such as Simulink, or with physical hardware in the loop (HIL).


REMINDER: You MUST include the sources above in your response to the user using markdown hyperlinks.

## Hybrid System Control - Search Results

Here are the key findings about hybrid system control:

### General Definition

In hybrid systems, the state is defined by the values of continuous variables and a discrete mode, with state changes occurring either continuously according to a flow condition or discretely according to a control graph.(no content)Continuous flow is permitted as long as invariants hold, while discrete transitions can occur when jump conditions are satisfied.

### Applications

Hybrid systems have been used to model several cyber-physical systems, including physical systems with impact, logic-dynamic controllers, and even Internet congestion.(no content)Hybrid automata have been used to model and analyze embedded systems including vehicle control systems, air traffic control systems, mobile robots, and processes from systems biology.

### Control in Hybrid Vehicles

Links: [{"title":"Discrete time and continuous time - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Discrete_time_and_continuous_time"},{"title":"Discrete system - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Discrete_system"},{"title":"Linear time-invariant system - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Linear_time-invariant_system"},{"title":"Observability Gramian - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Observability_Gramian"},{"title":"Controllability Gramian - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Controllability_Gramian"},{"title":"BIBO stability - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/BIBO_stability"},{"title":"Discrete-event simulation - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Discrete-event_simulation"},{"title":"Stochastic process - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Stochastic_process"},{"title":"DEVS - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/DEVS"},{"title":"Continuous simulation - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Continuous_simulation"}]

Here's comprehensive information about discrete time systems based on the search results:

## Definition and Characteristics

Discrete time views values of variables as occurring at distinct, separate "points in time", or equivalently as being unchanged throughout each non-zero region of time ("time period")—that is, time is viewed as a discrete variable.(no content)In theoretical computer science, a discrete system is a system with a countable number of states.(no content)Discrete systems may be contrasted with continuous systems, which may also be called analog systems.

## Discrete-Time Signals

A discrete signal or discrete-time signal is a time series consisting of a sequence of quantities. Unlike a continuous-time signal, a discrete-time signal is not a function of a continuous argument; however, it may have been obtained by sampling from a continuous-time signal.(no content)A discrete-time signal has a countable domain, like the natural numbers.

## Applications and Analysis

A discrete-time linear time-invariant (or, more generally, "shift-invariant") system is defined as one operating in discrete time.(no content)Almost everything in continuous-time systems has a counterpart in discrete-time systems. In many contexts, a discrete time (DT) system is really part of a larger continuous time (CT) system. For example, a digital recording system takes an analog sound, digitizes it, possibly processes the digital signals, and plays back an analog sound for people to listen to.

## Stability Concepts

For a discrete time LTI system, the condition for BIBO stability is that the impulse response be absolutely summable.

Links: [{"title":"Control theory - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Control_theory"},{"title":"Perceptual control theory - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Perceptual_control_theory"},{"title":"Social control theory - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Social_control_theory"},{"title":"Control theory (sociology) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Control_theory_(sociology)"},{"title":"Affect control theory - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Affect_control_theory"},{"title":"Closed system (control theory) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Closed_system_(control_theory)"},{"title":"Plant (control theory) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Plant_(control_theory)"},{"title":"Classical control theory - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Classical_control_theory"},{"title":"Compensator (control theory) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Compensator_(control_theory)"},{"title":"Control (optimal control theory) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Control_(optimal_control_theory)"}]

## Control Theory

Control theory is a field of control engineering and applied mathematics that deals with the control of dynamical systems.(no content)The aim is to develop a model or algorithm governing the application of system inputs to drive the system to a desired state, while minimizing any delay, overshoot, or steady-state error and ensuring a level of control stability; often with the aim to achieve a degree of optimality.

### How It Works

A controller monitors the controlled process variable (PV), and compares it with the reference or set point (SP). The difference between actual and desired value of the process variable, called the error signal, is applied as feedback to generate a control action to bring the controlled process variable to the same value as the set point.

### Applications

Control theory is used in control system engineering to design automation that have revolutionized manufacturing, aircraft, communications and other industries, and created new fields such as robotics.(no content)Control theory is routinely applied to problems both the natural and behavioral sciences. As the general theory of feedback systems, control theory is useful wherever feedback occurs, making it important to fields like economics, operations research, and the life sciences.

### Historical Development

Control theory dates from the 19th century, when the theoretical basis for the operation of governors was first described by James Clerk Maxwell.(no content)Control theory was further advanced by Edward Routh in 1874, Charles Sturm and in 1895, Adolf Hurwitz, who all contributed to the establishment of control stability criteria; and from 1922 onwards, the development of PID control theory by Nicolas Minorsky.

Based on the search results, here's comprehensive information about temporal logic:

## Overview

Temporal logic is any system of rules and symbolism for representing, and reasoning about, propositions qualified in terms of time (for example, "I am always hungry", "I will eventually be hungry", or "I will be hungry until I eat something").(no content)In a temporal logic, a statement can have a truth value that varies in time—in contrast with an atemporal logic, which applies only to statements whose truth values are constant in time.

## Key Characteristics

Temporal logic has two main approaches to reasoning about time:

- Linear-time logics are restricted to reasoning about a timeline.
- Branching-time logics can reason about multiple timelines, which permits in particular treatment of environments that may act unpredictably.

## History and Development

Temporal logic is sometimes used to refer to tense logic, a modal logic-based system of temporal logic introduced by Arthur Prior in the late 1950s, with important contributions by Hans Kamp.(no content)Prior published "Time and Modality" in 1957, in which he introduced a propositional modal logic with two temporal connectives (modal operators), F and P, corresponding to "sometime in the future" and "sometime in the past".

## Applications

Temporal logic has found an important application in formal verification, where it is used to state requirements of hardware or software systems. For instance, one may wish to say that whenever a request is made, access to a resource is eventually granted, but it is never granted to two requestors simultaneously. Such a statement can conveniently be expressed in a temporal logic.

## Variants

Some notable variants include:
- Linear temporal logic (LTL) is a modal temporal logic with modalities referring to time.
- Metric temporal logic is an extension of temporal logic in which temporal operators are replaced by time-constrained versions like until, next, since and previous operators.
- Temporal logic of actions (TLA) is a logic developed by Leslie Lamport, which combines temporal logic with a logic of actions. It is used to describe behaviours of concurrent and distributed systems.

1. [completed] Read ./triples_output.json. Classify paper as "contribution" or "survey". Edit triples_output.json to set paper_type field.

2. [completed] List ALL triples EXPLICITLY mentioned in title/abstract. For each, determine entity_type and relation.

3. [completed] For each triple: Use WebSearch tool with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] to search "[entity name]" to find the correct Wikipedia article. IMPORTANT: Always include allowed_domains parameter to restrict to English Wikipedia.

4. [in_progress] Edit triples_output.json to add all triples. For each triple: name: Use the Wikipedia article title (e.g., "Gradient descent" not "gradient descent algorithm"), relation: how paper relates to entity (uses or proposes), entity_type: one of task, method, data, artifact, tool, concept, other, wikipedia_url: The Wikipedia URL from search results (must start with https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/), relevance: 1 sentence explaining why it matters

5. [pending] Run validation: python validate_triple_json.py

6. [pending] If validation errors: Fix the errors (use WebSearch with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] again if needed for incorrect URLs), edit triples_output.json, and rerun validation. MUST REPEAT until validation passes.

Web search results for query: "Barrier function control"

Links: [{"title":"Barrier function - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Barrier_function"},{"title":"Barrier certificate - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Barrier_certificate"},{"title":"Barrier (computer science) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Barrier_(computer_science)"},{"title":"Interior-point method - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Interior-point_method"},{"title":"Traffic barrier - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Armco_barrier"},{"title":"Air barrier - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Air_barriers"},{"title":"Self-concordant function - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Self-concordant_function"},{"title":"Schottky barrier - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Schottky_barrier"},{"title":"Rectangular potential barrier - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Potential_barrier"},{"title":"Crowd control barrier - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Crowd_control_barrier"}]

Based on the search results, "barrier function control" can refer to several different contexts:

## Mathematical Optimization

In constrained optimization, a barrier function is a continuous function whose value increases to infinity as its argument approaches the boundary of the feasible region of an optimization problem. Such functions are used to replace inequality constraints by a penalizing term in the objective function that is easier to handle.(no content)The two most common types of barrier functions are inverse barrier functions and logarithmic barrier functions.(no content)Interior-point methods (also referred to as barrier methods) are algorithms for solving linear and non-linear convex optimization problems. They combine theoretical advantages of polynomial run-time—in contrast to the simplex method, which has exponential run-time in the worst case.

## Control Theory

In control theory, a barrier certificate or barrier function is used to prove that a given region is forward invariant for a given ordinary differential equation or hybrid dynamical system. That is, a barrier function can be used to show that if a solution starts in a given set, then it cannot leave that set.(no content)There are different types of barrier functions, including zeroing barrier functions and reciprocal barrier functions. Zeroing barrier functions may be preferred in embedded applications as they do not create unbounded values close to the set boundary.

If you're looking for information about a specific application of barrier function control, please let me know and I can search for more targeted information.


REMINDER: You MUST include the sources above in your response to the user using markdown hyperlinks.

Based on the search results, "barrier function control" can refer to several different contexts:

## Mathematical Optimization

In constrained optimization, a barrier function is a continuous function whose value increases to infinity as its argument approaches the boundary of the feasible region of an optimization problem. Such functions are used to replace inequality constraints by a penalizing term in the objective function that is easier to handle.(no content)The two most common types of barrier functions are inverse barrier functions and logarithmic barrier functions.(no content)Interior-point methods (also referred to as barrier methods) are algorithms for solving linear and non-linear convex optimization problems. They combine theoretical advantages of polynomial run-time—in contrast to the simplex method, which has exponential run-time in the worst case.

## Control Theory

In control theory, a barrier certificate or barrier function is used to prove that a given region is forward invariant for a given ordinary differential equation or hybrid dynamical system. That is, a barrier function can be used to show that if a solution starts in a given set, then it cannot leave that set.(no content)There are different types of barrier functions, including zeroing barrier functions and reciprocal barrier functions. Zeroing barrier functions may be preferred in embedded applications as they do not create unbounded values close to the set boundary.

If you're looking for information about a specific application of barrier function control, please let me know and I can search for more targeted information.

message_text:
Web search results for query: "Lyapunov function"

Links: [{"title":"Lyapunov function - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lyapunov_function"},{"title":"Control-Lyapunov function - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Control-Lyapunov_function"},{"title":"Lyapunov equation - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lyapunov_equation"},{"title":"Lyapunov stability - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lyapunov_stability"},{"title":"Lyapunov optimization - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lyapunov_optimization"},{"title":"Lyapunov–Schmidt reduction - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lyapunov%E2%80%93Schmidt_reduction"},{"title":"Input-to-state stability - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Input-to-state_stability"},{"title":"Central limit theorem - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Central_limit_theorem"},{"title":"Lyapunov vector - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lyapunov_vector"},{"title":"Conley's fundamental theorem of dynamical systems - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Conley's_fundamental_theorem_of_dynamical_systems"}]

Here are the search results for "Lyapunov function":

## Overview

In the theory of ordinary differential equations (ODEs), Lyapunov functions, named after Aleksandr Lyapunov, are scalar functions that may be used to prove the stability of an equilibrium of an ODE.(no content)Lyapunov functions (also called Lyapunov's second method for stability) are important to stability theory of dynamical systems and control theory.

## Key Properties and Conditions

For certain classes of ODEs, the existence of Lyapunov functions is a necessary and sufficient condition for stability. However, there is no general technique for constructing Lyapunov functions for ODEs, in many specific cases the construction of Lyapunov functions is known.

## How They Work

The Lyapunov stability criterion or the Direct Method makes use of a Lyapunov function V(x) which has an analogy to the potential function of classical dynamics.(no content)A Lyapunov function is a nonnegative scalar measure of a multi-dimensional state. Typically, the function is defined to grow large when the system moves towards undesirable states.

## Applications and Extensions

Beyond standard Lyapunov functions, there are several related concepts:

- A control-Lyapunov function (CLF) is an extension of the idea of Lyapunov function to systems with control inputs.
- Lyapunov optimization refers to the use of a Lyapunov function to optimally control a dynamical system. Lyapunov functions are used extensively in control theory to ensure different forms of system stability.
- Input-to-state stability (ISS) is a stability notion widely used to study stability of nonlinear control systems with external inputs. A control system is ISS if it is globally asymptotically stable in the absence of external inputs and if its trajectories are bounded by a function of the size of the input for all sufficiently large times.

Perfect! Analysis complete. Here's a summary of what was accomplished:

## Analysis Summary

**Paper Classification:** Contribution

**Key Findings:**
The paper "Formal Synthesis of Stochastic Systems via Control Barrier Certificates" proposes a novel method for synthesizing control policies for discrete-time stochastic systems with temporal logic specifications.

**Extracted Triples (10 total):**

**Uses (9 entities):**
1. **Control theory** (concept) - Provides the fundamental mathematical framework
2. **Stochastic control** (method) - Handles systems with uncertainty and randomness
3. **Linear temporal logic** (concept) - Formalizes complex temporal properties
4. **Automata theory** (concept) - Decomposes temporal logic specifications
5. **Reachability** (task) - Core problem addressed by the approach
6. **Hybrid system** (concept) - Models systems with continuous/discrete dynamics
7. **Vehicle dynamics** (task) - Application domain tested (lane-keeping control)
8. **Discrete time and continuous time** (concept) - Framework for modeling discrete-time systems
9. **Temporal logic** (concept) - Broader framework for temporal specifications

**Proposes (1 entity):**
1. **Barrier certificate** (method) - Extended as control barrier certificates for solving reachability with probability bounds

All Wikipedia URLs have been validated and the JSON file passes validation with ✅ success.

- [Control theory](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Control_theory)
